channel.title: The New York Times Trends
channel.description: 用中文浏览纽约时报热门报道

item.title: 50,000 people have fled Ukraine in the past 48 hours according to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, the U.S. ambassador to the UN said. "We have a solemn obligation to not look away." https://t.co/5j1wsw5elD
Breaking News: Russia vetoed a United Nations Security Council resolution that would have condemned the country’s invasion of Ukraine. https://t.co/AkjZDNKK0R

Canada's deputy prime minister, Chrystia Freeland, whose mother was Ukrainian-Canadian, said that President Vladimir Putin had cemented his place “in the ranks of the reviled European dictators who caused such carnage in the 20th century.” https://t.co/7b5wedB8kP https://t.co/107HqGJEKH

The body of a Russian soldier lay next to an armored vehicle that Ukrainian soldiers said was Russian, in Kharkiv, Ukraine, on Friday.
Ukraine’s military was waging a fierce battle to push Russian forces back from the city a day after a vicious fight. https://t.co/E3ld2rfsqy https://t.co/cMJhxyb3C2

Volunteer fighters are now patrolling central Kyiv after President Volodymyr Zelensky’s call for Ukrainians to defend their country.
Follow the latest on Russia's invasion of Ukraine here: https://t.co/FmlvmFFRYN https://t.co/HACJVpXspA

"The president is here." President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine posted a video on social media showing him standing alongside other government officials, saying that the country’s leaders had not fled Kyiv as Russian forces entered the city. https://t.co/VPxc01QGAG https://t.co/F91xlEp7we

Before Russia invaded Ukraine, Donald Trump called President Vladimir Putin's wartime strategy "pretty smart." Now, pro-Putin sentiment has spread across social media, right-wing podcasts, Telegram and some conservative media. https://t.co/bpI4jO9v2h
Breaking News: The U.S. is planning to levy sanctions against Vladimir Putin as soon as today, an official said, following a similar move from the E.U. https://t.co/n0h06kHSKv

The Russian attack on Ukraine has prompted a flurry of activity among far-right European militia leaders, who are raising funds, recruiting fighters and planning travel to the front lines to confront the country’s invaders, according to a research group. https://t.co/EscFZyMozi

President Volodymyr Zelensky asked Israel's prime minister to mediate negotiations between Ukraine and Russia. "They didn’t say no,” the Ukrainian ambassador to Israel said. "They are trying to figure out where they are in this chess play." https://t.co/p9IKD3jOkA

NATO leaders conducted a rare emergency summit on Friday and agreed to deploy more troops to the eastern members of the alliance. Those deployments would involve thousands of troops, some of them from the U.S., and more than 100 jets put on high alert. https://t.co/VWY3pLieAV

In Opinion
Vladimir Putin’s “attack on Ukraine represents, in many ways, a failure of the Western approach to European security of the past 30 years,” writes Emma Ashford, a security fellow, in a guest essay. https://t.co/qjWBGI88Pt

Watch: Video and photographs verified by The New York Times appear to show two bridges that lead to Kyiv were destroyed, a new tactic that Ukraine seems to use to slow down the advancing Russian forces. https://t.co/hX9N4cc18W

No Russian act will be allowed to participate in this year’s Eurovision Song Contest, organizers announced on Friday, citing fears that Russia’s inclusion would damage the reputation of the competition, which is meant to promote European unity. https://t.co/W7LU350kiP

A group founded by the former NFL quarterback Colin Kaepernick started this week to offer free secondary autopsies for families of people who died under “police-related” circumstances. https://t.co/x0MEOfWwof

Sally Kellerman, the actress and singer whose portrayal of Maj. Margaret (Hot Lips) Houlihan in the 1970 dark comedy “MASH” earned her an Oscar nomination, died on Thursday. She was 84. https://t.co/6TX3ZAgQej

The U.S. and Europe imposed economic sanctions on Russia after its invasion of Ukraine. Do sanctions really work? @SangerNYT leads a discussion with @RichardHaass, @PatcohenNYT and @ewong. Join us now. https://t.co/MCpVsbkC6J https://t.co/rnaR1x3Tgo

Ukraine’s military on Friday was waging a fierce battle to push Russian forces back from Ukraine’s second-largest city, Kharkiv, a day after a vicious fight that littered the highway leading into the city with Russian troop carriers and at least one body. https://t.co/aclNYsCict https://t.co/em2GxUDwHX

Ukrainians in a southern neighborhood of Kyiv sorted through the wreckage of a residential building that was hit by missiles early on Friday. Officials warned residents to stay indoors and “prepare Molotov cocktails” to defend against Russian forces. https://t.co/DBgrxilMuY https://t.co/MfcRubQ0AS

President Biden selected Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson as his nominee to the Supreme Court, people briefed on his decision said. If confirmed, she would become the first Black woman to serve as a justice, replacing Justice Stephen Breyer, who is retiring. https://t.co/BSpKOOrPCC

Breaking News: Russian forces have lost momentum in the invasion of Ukraine, a senior Defense Department official said. But Pentagon officials warned that as of Friday morning Russia had sent into Ukraine only 30% of its troops amassed at the border. https://t.co/cEIC2JspAL

As the Ukrainian capital, Kyiv, came under siege, an exodus of tired, frightened people tried to head west with what they could carry. They packed train cars with windows closed and lights off so as not to be a target for Russian missiles. https://t.co/Bq1c3TMKC8 https://t.co/bjbFkBhOkC

NEW TIME: The U.S. and Europe imposed economic sanctions on Russia after its invasion of Ukraine. Do sanctions really work? @SangerNYT leads a discussion with @RichardHaass, @PatcohenNYT and @ewong today at 1 p.m. ET. DM questions to @nytimesevents. https://t.co/IYXPt7M6yA

Russia’s attack has taken on such large unpredictable dimensions that even people living far from what were expected to be the main combat zones in Ukraine are taking flight and racing to border crossings into Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania. https://t.co/JSLTvlICie https://t.co/D7NeNFlAna

As Russian troops pour into Ukraine, officials in Beijing fumed at any suggestion they are betraying a core principle of Chinese foreign policy — that sovereignty is sacred — in order to shield Moscow. But it's clear Russia’s war has put Beijing in a bind. https://t.co/sWDCkifPSc

President Vladimir Putin on Friday called on Ukrainian soldiers to lay down their arms. He described President Volodymyr Zelensky’s government as a “band of drug addicts and neo-Nazis” and said it had taken “hostage the entire Ukrainian people.” https://t.co/tMjZe6KGLX

Volunteers and activists have propped up Ukraine’s poorly funded military for years. When troops went to war against Russia on Thursday, so did they.
“We were getting ready for this for years,” said a neurosurgeon who volunteers as a battlefield medic. https://t.co/IfxoT30UNg

Volunteers lined up to receive their weapons on Friday after the Ukrainian government’s announcement that it would arm civilians to resist the Russian invasion. Once armed, they took cover as jets flew overhead. https://t.co/NPiAq4KROd https://t.co/oqjk9gOhDi

Breaking News: The EU will freeze the assets of President Vladimir Putin of Russia and his foreign minister, Sergey Lavrov, but will not impose a travel ban on them, two diplomats said. https://t.co/BTYGUwXsYy https://t.co/tZ94vMLASB

Ukraine’s foreign minister accused Russian forces of attacking a kindergarten and an orphanage. He said the Ukrainian authorities would send evidence of the attacks to The Hague, tweeting, “Responsibility is inevitable.” https://t.co/uUjOu5RpPZ https://t.co/440hdgFIjx

Ukrainian border guards who died defending Snake Island when Russia attacked will all be posthumously titled "Hero of Ukraine."
In an audio clip, they used an expletive and refused to surrender the Black Sea island when ordered to by a Russian warship. https://t.co/FbepkPTO4r

Formula 1 canceled the Russian Grand Prix, saying that it would be “impossible” to hold the race “in the current circumstances.”
The decision came after UEFA, European soccer’s governing body, moved the Champions League final to Paris from St. Petersburg. https://t.co/G6SkkaBwiJ

Russia’s attack against Ukraine — one of the most significant military actions in Europe since World War II — raises the prospect of a rekindled Cold War.
Here’s how Ukraine became a flash point between Russia and the West. https://t.co/YlcRjuRrE8 https://t.co/r1SO599Zn6

Ukraine’s defense ministry, in a Facebook post, warned residents in a district in northern Kyiv of fighting with Russian forces nearby, telling them to stay home and prepare Molotov cocktails.
Follow live updates. https://t.co/4OtuherPMG

A jury found three former Minneapolis police officers guilty of violating George Floyd’s civil rights during the arrest that killed him, by failing to intervene when Derek Chauvin pressed his knee on Floyd's neck for over nine minutes. https://t.co/GB6AbDpdUy https://t.co/SqkPgUXXW3

Myanmar’s military junta backed Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, even as the country’s shadow civilian government condemned the attack.
“Russia has done its part to maintain its sovereignty, and I think it is the right thing to do,” a junta spokesman said. https://t.co/15VlMLrzsC

President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine switched to speaking Russian during his latest video address, calling on President Vladimir Putin to enter negotiations to stop the war. https://t.co/qApucr5quy https://t.co/i8w1ApNmD0

The U.S. and Europe responded to Russia's invasion of Ukraine with economic sanctions. Do sanctions really work? @SangerNYT leads a discussion with @RichardHaass, @PatcohenNYT and @ewong on Friday, Feb. 25, at 2 p.m. ET. DM questions to @nytimesevents. https://t.co/Vbu232YAFf

The front page of The New York Times for Feb. 25, 2022.
Follow our updates on the Russian invasion of Ukraine. https://t.co/DasJqSwcBA https://t.co/aJ9rzN94wD

Britain’s defense secretary said that Russian forces had failed to meet any of their goals in the first day of their invasion of Ukraine, citing the verified assessment of his country’s intelligence services. https://t.co/W7agOpQ8OP

European leaders agreed to a new set of sanctions on Russia, which they described as unprecedented for the EU in terms of size and reach. The measures will hit Russia’s access to technology and its elite’s abilities to travel and save money in Europe. https://t.co/UoS4ppcRxm

Kyiv, the Ukrainian capital, was hit by missile strikes on Friday, the second day of Russia’s military offensive. Ukraine’s leaders told residents to “prepare Molotov cocktails” to defend the city.
Follow our updates on the Russian invasion of Ukraine. https://t.co/8SpMVtutQe https://t.co/1DJdgusZpL

The Taliban called on Russia and Ukraine to resolve the crisis through “peaceful means.”
They asked both countries to safeguard Afghans in Ukraine. Ukrainian troops evacuated nearly 100 Afghans to Kyiv after the fall of Afghanistan’s government in August. https://t.co/Q89NxxkkJC

The U.S. met with China over three months to present intelligence showing Russia’s troop buildup near Ukraine and to urge Beijing to help avert war, U.S. officials said.
Chinese officials rebuffed the U.S. and shared the information with Moscow. https://t.co/Ngbuu9P3n1
UEFA, European soccer’s governing body, voted to move the Champions League final to Paris from St. Petersburg as punishment for Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. https://t.co/TQpib57MBc

A large rocket landed in the middle of the street near the National Guard academy in Kharkiv, Ukraine’s second-largest city. It was unclear if anyone was injured by the rocket, which failed to detonate.
Follow our updates on the Ukraine crisis. https://t.co/gzBSYhRUzy https://t.co/INGOkm8bBV

Kyiv was hit by missile strikes, with a rocket crashing into a residential building, as Russian forces pressed closer to the heart of the government.
Ukraine’s Defense Ministry urged people in the capital to stay indoors and “prepare Molotov cocktails.” https://t.co/cBrs6BNTeA https://t.co/rGqyJJXZD6

India's prime minister, Narendra Modi, said he appealed to President Vladimir Putin of Russia for a “cessation of violence,” but he fell short of condemning Russia's invasion of Ukraine. https://t.co/MkQ3W1XS5I

The UN Security Council on Friday plans to vote on a resolution condemning Russia’s invasion of Ukraine and calling for an immediate and unconditional withdrawal of its troops, according to a senior U.S. administration official. https://t.co/2QN0CYwQfF

Ukrainian border guards who died defending Snake Island when Russia attacked will all be posthumously titled "Hero of Ukraine."
In an audio clip, they used an expletive and refused to surrender the Black Sea island when ordered to by a Russian warship. https://t.co/jz1iNDDw7u
